TitleText: 1	Lantern Festival in Taipei lights up the night
LeftText: 4	— The Taipei City Lantern Festival was off to a bright start on Saturday Night
5	as hundreds of thousands of people crowded onto the Chiang Kai Shek Memorial near downtown Taipei
6	to witness city mayor Hau Lung - bin
7	and other dignitaries ceremoniously flip the switch
8	to light hundreds of colorful lantern scenes in and around the 240,000 square meter memorial park .
9	The centerpiece of this rock concert - like performance is a 15 meter high rotating pig
10	equipped with a fog machine , laser light show and theme music .
11	The theme of this year s lantern festival revolves around the 12 year Chinese zodiac cycle s year of the pig .
12	Its round shape symbolizes wealth and good fortune
13	and is believed to bring good luck .
14	Started in 1990 ,
15	the Taipei lantern festival continues a 2000 year old tradition of light related festivals
16	marking the end of the Chinese New Year celebrations .
17	This particular event grows in popularity every year .
18	Last Year over 4 million visitors attended the event
19	and this year the city expects about 6 million visitors
20	according to the event website .

LeftText: 14	Started in 1990 ,
15	the Taipei lantern festival continues a 2000 year old tradition of light related festivals
16	marking the end of the Chinese New Year celebrations .
RightText: 17	This particular event grows in popularity every year .
18	Last Year over 4 million visitors attended the event
19	and this year the city expects about 6 million visitors
20	according to the event website .
21	Colorful lantern scenes not only fill the central square
22	but also the surrounding 2 km circumference of the memorial .
23	Each section has a theme .
24	One side of the memorial is scenes
25	made by student groups
26	while other areas represent the counties of Taiwan .
27	There is even a section of lanterns
28	sponsored by foreign countries .
29	The Malaysia Tourism board was quite prominent at the main entrance to the grounds .
30	As with all new year celebrations in Taiwan , the lantern festival is crowded .
31	People flock
32	to see the lantern scenes
33	and enjoy the festival atmosphere
34	as they carry lanterns ,
35	given away by the city
36	and bought from street vendors at the event .
37	The many light toys such a swords , devil ears , and lanterns turn the milling crowd into a unique light show
38	that can be observed
39	by climbing the steps of the 70 meter memorial hall on the grounds .
40	Local public transportation hubs are often swamped by the event .
41	The station staff at Chiang Kai Shek Memorial Hall Station do an excellent job of crowd control
42	but lines for the subway can still be hours long and very exhausting .
43	A sudden rain storm on Sunday night
44	( March 4 )
45	caused a mass exodus of people to head for the station prompting lines
46	that backed up into the street .
47	The commuting crowds can be avoided however
48	by walking from NTU Hospital Station or Shandao Station .
49	Both of these stops are only about a 20 minute walk from the event
50	and have no crowds at all .
51	If you really want to avoid the crowds ,
52	definitely avoid the weekends .
53	Wait until the fourth or fifth day of the festival
54	when the crowds will have dwindled .
55	I visited the festival on Saturday night , the opening night ,
56	and there was a sea of people in the square .
57	I went back the next Tuesday night
58	and there was almost no one there ,
59	just a few stray photographers
60	taking advantage of the unimpeded views of the lanterns .
61	The festival runs through March 11 this year .
